question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
Directly plugging in x=1 into the limit gives 0/0. We try to factor to cancel out the terms making the fraction zero.

\[\begin{aligned} &\lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{x^2+2x-3}{x-1}}\\ &=\lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{(x-1)(x+3)}{x-1}}\\ &=\lim_{x\to 1}(x+3)\\ &= (1) + 3\\ &=4\end{aligned}\]

Directly plugging in x=1 into the limit gives 0/0. Since this is an indeterminate form, we can use L’Hospital’s rule:

\[\begin{aligned} &\lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{x^2+2x-3}{x-1}}\\ &=\lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{(x^2+2x-3)'}{(x-1)'}}\\ &=\lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{2x+2}{1}}\\ &=\lim_{x\to 1}{2x+2}\\ &=2(1)+2\\ &=4\end{aligned}\]

\end{align*}

\end{align*}

statement_html:
Evaluate

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lim_{x\to 1}{\frac{x^2+2x-3}{x-1}}\end{aligned}\]

Or determine that this limit does not exist.
